data.title: Mistral AI teams with Accenture to boost enterprise AI adoption in Europe
data.description:
• French artificial intelligence company Mistral AI announced on Thursday that it has teamed up with Accenture (ACN) to boost enterprise adoption of AI in Europe and around the world.
  • As part of the deal, Mistral AI, which is backed by Microsoft (MSFT), will work with Accenture to co-develop and deliver enterprise AI solutions across sectors, the companies said in a statement. “This joint approach will help enterprises capture value quickly and securely, supported by Accenture’s global network of AI specialists and its deep understanding of industry processes, regulatory environments and transformation needs,” the companies added.
  • Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.
  • “We are proud to partner with Accenture, whose international reach and industry depth make them an ideal partner to continue driving AI transformations for enterprises at scale,” Arthur Mensch, CEO and co-founder of Mistral AI, said. “Together, we will help organizations deploy AI that meets their needs for performance, control, and customization. This collaboration marks an important milestone for industries around the world to realize the ROI of AI.”
  • Mistral AI said earlier this month that it will acquire cloud computing service provider Koyeb for an undisclosed amount.

data.title: Barclays, Santander, Wells Fargo in Street lenders exposed to failed UK-based MFS - report
data.description:
Barclays (BCS) (BCLYF), Banco Santander (SAN) (BCDRF), and Wells Fargo (WFC) are said to be among the Wall Street lenders exposed to the failed UK mortgage finance firm, Market Financial Solutions.

Apollo Global Management (APO) unit Atlas SP Partners; Jefferies Financial Group (JEF); and Castlelake LP, majority owned by Brookfield (BN), are also exposed to MFS, Bloomberg News reported, citing people familiar with the matter. 

This month, the UK-based specialist property finance solutions provider MFS entered into administration.

Barclays and Atlas had helped arrange over £2B of loans to the firm, lending hundreds of millions of dollars, the Thursday, February 26 report noted.

Barclays had about £600M tied up in the matter, a judge overseeing the MFS insolvency case reportedly said at the hearing.

Meanwhile, Atlas was involved as a senior creditor and is pursuing all legal avenues to maximize recoveries on £400M of exposure, a spokesperson told Bloomberg.

Furthermore, Jefferies had an exposure of ~£100M to MFS, according to a person familiar with the matter.

And, Castlelake had arranged a lending facility, which has around £400M outstanding, one of the people reportedly said. However, a Castlelake spokesperson told Bloomberg in an emailed statement that they do not have direct unsecured exposure to MFS.

The MFS issue could increase concerns relating to loose underwriting in credit markets, Bloomberg noted.

data.title: Equinix, CPPIB near $4B deal for atNorth - Bloomberg
data.description:
Equinix Inc. (EQIX) and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board are close to an agreement to acquire atNorth Holding AB, a pan-Nordic data center operator.

The consortium is close to a deal that could value atNorth at about $4 billion, including debt, according to a  Bloomberg report on Thursday, which cited people familiar with the matter. A purchase of atNorth, which is owned by Partners Group Holding (PGPHF), may be announced as soon as this week.

While talks are advanced, a possible deal could still face delays, according to the report.

CPPIB, Equinix and Partners Group declined to comment to Bloomberg.

data.title: Chemed cut to Neutral at BofA after Q4 miss
data.description:
Chemed (CHE) shares hit a new 52-week low on Thursday after the hospice and palliative care services provider missed Street forecasts with its Q4 2025 financials, prompting Bank of America to downgrade the stock to Neutral from Buy.

With its quarterly results on Wednesday after the close, the Cincinnati, Ohio-based company posted $6.42 of adjusted EPS on $639.3M of revenue, falling short of the consensus by $0.61 and $19.8M, respectively.

The company’s topline remained relatively flat from the prior year period as revenue from its Roto-Rooter segment dropped ~4% YoY to $220.6M, while its Vitas segment added $418.8M with a ~2% YoY growth.

BofA analyst Joanna Gajuk issued the downgrade, mainly citing headwinds in Roto-Rooter, which offers plumbing, drain cleaning, and water cleanup services in the U.S. and international markets, including Canada.

Gajuk, who lowered her price target on CHE to $450 from $595, argued that Roto-Rooter’s EBITDA has contracted for three consecutive years and the firm missed its initial outlook, “leaving us cautious on the 2026 guide and ability to grow that biz.”

However, the analyst argued that Roto-Rooter’s bleak outlook was offset by the Vitas segment, which she identified as a relatively stable business with “more sustainable growth." Gajuk stopped short of issuing a bearish rating on CHE, citing a potential upside thanks to the strong cash flows of both units.

data.title: Quantum computing stocks diverge from the broader tech selloff
data.description:
Quantum computing stocks outperformed the broader technology sector on Thursday, advancing even as weakness across large-cap tech weighed on major indexes.

Shares of IonQ (IONQ) surged more than 20% after the company released its latest quarterly results, with investors responding positively to updates surrounding bookings, commercial partnerships, and progress on system development. 

Meanwhile, D-Wave Quantum (QBTS) gained roughly 2% following its earnings report, which highlighted ongoing customer adoption and advancements in its annealing quantum computing platform. 

The gains stood in contrast to broader declines within the technology space, where semiconductor and mega-cap names faced renewed selling pressure. Thursday’s divergence underscores the market’s growing appetite for emerging technology themes, particularly those tied to next-generation computing. 

While quantum computing remains an early-stage industry characterized by elevated volatility and long commercialization timelines, investor interest appears resilient as companies demonstrate incremental operational progress and expanding enterprise engagement.

Quantum Computing ETFs: (QTUM), (WQTM), and (QNTM).

Tech ETFs: (VGT), (XLK), (IYW), (FTEC), (IXN), and (RSPT).

data.title: Eos Energy targets $300M–$400M revenue in 2026 while addressing operational challenges and ramping automation
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Eos Energy Enterprises (EOSE) Q4 2025

Management View

  • CEO Joseph Mastrangelo highlighted that "our volume was up. Our margins improved sequentially quarter-over-quarter and year-over-year. We had a great quarter as far as orders being booked," but clarified, "the bottom line is we missed our guidance, and that falls on me as the CEO of the company."
  • Mastrangelo indicated the company is expanding its installed base, now covering 20% of the United States with 20 projects, and targets reaching 25% coverage in the next few months, with international expansion into Germany and the U.K. planned.
  • He emphasized, "on the bottom, yes, 7x year-over-year growth on revenue, combined with our highest cash position that we've had in the company's history, along with closing the gap and moving towards profitability, we've removed the going concern language inside of our 10-K filing."
  • The launch of the Indensity product was announced, described as an evolution of existing technology focused on easier operation, serviceability, and manufacturing.
  • COO John Mehas stated, "Q4 was my first full quarter at Eos... we completed our subassembly automation, making our battery line fully automated. We closed 2025 with production records across all operations and delivered our fourth consecutive quarter of record revenue."
  • Mehas acknowledged, "we fell short of our operational targets, and that's on me," citing supplier nonperformance, automation quality issues, and higher-than-expected downtime as key challenges now being addressed.
  • Interim CFO & Chief Commercial Officer Nathan Kroeker reported, "we ended the quarter with just over $701 million in backlog, booking nearly 1.1 gigawatt hours across 8 customers and 9 individual projects, representing a 9% sequential increase. During the quarter, we secured more than $240 million in new orders."
  • Kroeker added, "we ended the year with just under $625 million worth of cash on the balance sheet, the strongest cash position in the company's history."

Outlook

  • Mastrangelo stated, "Let me wrap up with our outlook on 2026 as we initiate guidance on revenue. You can see the progression of our guidance from 7x. If you take the midpoint of the guidance range in 2026, it's 3x what we did in 2025."
  • The revenue guidance for 2026 is set at a range of $300 million to $400 million, with the lower end supported by backlog and the upper range dependent on larger project approvals and Indensity shipments in the latter half of the year.
  • Mastrangelo explained, "we feel very confident on the guide that we're giving on the range of $300 million to $400 million."
  • He also noted, "we will be gross margin positive in the second half of 2026."

Financial Results

  • Kroeker reported, "in the fourth quarter, we generated $58 million in revenue, nearly double Q3. We exceeded the combined revenue of the first 3 quarters of 2025 as well as all prior year revenue combined since the company went public."
  • Full year revenue was $114.2 million, described as "more than 7x year-over-year growth."
  • Full year gross loss was $143.8 million, with adjusted gross loss at $128.5 million. Operating expenses totaled $115.4 million, with noncash items making up $25 million.
  • Net loss for the year was $969.6 million, including $746.8 million of noncash impacts primarily from mark-to-market revaluations due to the company's stock price increase.
  • Adjusted EBITDA loss was $219.1 million, with margin improvement noted.

Q&A

  • Stephen Gengaro, Stifel: Asked about guidance credibility and risk controls after missing Q4 guidance. Mastrangelo replied, "we tried to really look at how we can change our discipline as a company to not have happened what happened in 2025."
  • Julien Dumoulin-Smith, Jefferies: Inquired about the specifics behind larger projects and backlog duration. Mastrangelo pointed to NYSERDA projects and PJM initiatives, but stressed "approvals and queues are long."
  • Dumoulin-Smith also asked about defense sector opportunities, to which Mastrangelo responded that the company is working through government processes and requirements, leveraging its American-made product.
  • Mark Strouse, JPMorgan: Asked about the competitive landscape. Mastrangelo said, "there's many different use cases," emphasizing Eos' competitive positioning for 4- to 16-hour storage and recent pipeline growth.
  • Craig Shere, Tuohy Brothers: Queried about international margins and cash flow. Mastrangelo said, "where we're seeing interest in our product internationally has less to do with politics and more to do with performance," and did not expect lower margins internationally.
  • Jeffrey Osborne, TD Cowen: Asked about production yields and field reliability. Mehas replied, "the goal for that automation is 97% first pass yield, and we're well on our way there."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts expressed skepticism regarding guidance reliability and questioned the company's ability to deliver on ambitious revenue targets, often pressing for specifics and risk mitigation strategies.
  • Management's tone in prepared remarks was confident and forward-looking, emphasizing improvement and operational discipline, but shifted to a more defensive posture during Q&A, acknowledging past guidance misses and operational setbacks. Mastrangelo used phrases such as "we feel very confident" and "we are focused on being good stewards of that capital."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, analyst questioning was more pointed, and management appeared more cautious in its outlook and explanations.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance shifted from reiterating $150 million to $160 million revenue for full-year 2025 in Q3, to projecting $300 million to $400 million for 2026.
  • Operational focus evolved from ramping initial automation and capacity in Q3 to addressing explicit execution shortfalls and planning redundancy and process improvements in Q4.
  • Analysts became more focused on risk, execution discipline, and margin evolution, compared to a previous emphasis on pipeline and growth.
  • Management's confidence level, while still present, was more tempered as they acknowledged missing Q4 guidance and detailed steps to improve execution reliability.

Risks and Concerns

  • Supplier nonperformance, automation quality issues, and excessive downtime were cited as major operational risks that impacted Q4 results.
  • Management is implementing better supplier controls, tooling improvements, and process changes to address these risks.
  • The lack of manufacturing redundancy remains a key risk until Line 2 is operational.
  • Revenue concentration and the timing of large project approvals present ongoing challenges for achieving top-end guidance.

Final Takeaway

Eos Energy management emphasized that while the company delivered record revenue growth and strengthened its cash position in 2025, execution challenges led to a miss in guidance. With a renewed focus on operational improvements, automation, and disciplined expansion, the company has set a 2026 revenue target of $300 million to $400 million and expects to achieve gross margin positivity in the second half of the year. Management underscored ongoing efforts to build long-term value through scalable technology, robust backlog, and prudent cash management, while recognizing the need for continued operational discipline to meet evolving market demands and investor expectations.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Dorman Products outlines 7%–9% 2026 sales growth target while advancing complex electronics and supply chain diversification
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Dorman Products (DORM) Q4 2025

Management View

  • Kevin Olsen, President, CEO & Director, reported that Dorman achieved record sales from new products in 2025, launched thousands of new SKUs, and made meaningful investments in product development, particularly in complex electronic solutions. He stated, "Our current new product pipeline is as strong as it's ever been with a growing mix of opportunities involving complex electronic solutions, an area where we believe we have a distinct competitive advantage."
  • Olsen highlighted operational advances: "We advanced productivity across the organization, including deploying new automation technologies in our distribution centers. These initiatives improved service levels for customers, enhanced availability for end users and generated tangible savings."
  • On supply chain, Olsen noted a strategic reduction of sourcing from China to below 40% in 2025, with a target of approximately 30% in 2026: "Strengthening supply chain resilience remains a key priority, and we continue to build deep strategic relationships with suppliers around the world."
  • Channel expansion was emphasized, particularly with new business in heavy-duty and specialty vehicle segments. Olsen explained, "With Dayton, we drove wins by leaning into categories where we had competitive advantages. And with SuperATV, we expanded our dealer network and nondiscretionary portfolio."
  • The company cited consolidated net sales of $2.13 billion for 2025, a 6% year-over-year increase, with adjusted diluted EPS for Q4 at $2.17. Olsen also announced the appointment of Charles Rayfield as incoming CFO.
  • CFO David Hession commented, "Adjusted gross margin came in higher than expected for the quarter at 42.6%. This was a 90 basis point increase compared to last year's fourth quarter."

Outlook

  • Dorman expects total net sales growth of 7% to 9% for 2026, "directionally the same range for each of the segments," according to Olsen.
  • Olsen provided additional cadence: "From a margin perspective, we expect operating margin will reduce temporarily in the first quarter, but we expect our margin profile will meaningfully improve through the back half of the year."
  • The company projects full-year operating margin in the range of 15% to 16%, with normalization to high teens by year-end 2026.
  • Adjusted diluted EPS guidance for 2026 is $8.10 to $8.50.
  • Olsen added, "Our guidance today reflects an assumption that future tariff levels will remain generally consistent with those that were in place prior to the IEEPA ruling, and therefore, we expect the overall impact to our business will likely be directionally the same."

Financial Results

  • Net sales in Q4 2025 were $538 million, up $4 million or approximately 1% year-over-year. Hession stated, "Adjusted operating income was $93 million and flat compared to last year's fourth quarter. Adjusted operating margin was 17.4%, down slightly compared to the same period."
  • The company reported $42 million in operating cash flow for Q4, and $25 million was returned to shareholders through share repurchases.
  • Full-year adjusted diluted EPS was $8.87, a 24% increase compared to 2024.
  • Hession quantified tariff impacts: "We estimate a full year impact of approximately $1.25 to our adjusted diluted EPS."
  • Net debt at year-end was $391 million, down $42 million from the prior year, with total liquidity at $648 million.

Q&A

  • Scott Stember, ROTH Capital: Questioned light-duty business volume versus pricing and the sustainability of mid-single-digit POS growth. Olsen responded, "Our POS was up mid-single digit in the quarter, very similar to what we saw in the third quarter."
  • Bret Jordan, Jefferies: Asked about inventory growth drivers. Olsen said, "The largest proportion of inventory growth that you've seen really starting at midyear...is the higher tariff cost."
  • Jeffrey Lick, Stephens: Sought clarity on drivers of anticipated sales acceleration. Olsen explained, "We had one of our largest customers shift their order patterns in the fourth quarter...orders were down from that customer nearly 40% from the third quarter. That's obviously not going to continue as we move through 2026."
  • Tristan Thomas-Martin, BMO: Inquired about complex electronics TAM. Olsen responded, "As we look at complex electronics, it continues to be a larger and larger portion of our portfolio...our new product opportunities looking out 3 years...is the highest proportion of that funnel than it's ever been."
  • David Lantz, Wells Fargo: Asked about segment growth and M&A strategy. Olsen described growth opportunities across all segments and explained, "If M&A opportunities don't present themselves, we look to return capital to shareholders."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts pressed for detailed breakdowns on volume versus pricing, inventory implications, and segment-specific growth, exhibiting a neutral to slightly skeptical tone, especially on the sustainability of growth and tariff effects.
  • Management maintained a confident tone in prepared remarks, using phrases such as "we're confident in the foundation we built" and "we have the playbook to handle the timing nuances," but was cautious about tariff-related uncertainties in Q&A.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management's confidence in innovation and supply chain progress was more pronounced, while analysts increased their focus on the effects of tariffs and inventory dynamics.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance for 2026 shifts to a 7%–9% net sales growth target, compared to reaffirmed 7%–9% guidance for 2025 in the previous call.
  • Management now provides more granular commentary on tariff impacts and their timing, as well as the normalization of ordering patterns from large customers, which was a less prominent issue previously.
  • Analysts continue to focus on growth drivers and tariff effects, but questions this quarter were more focused on inventory, margin cadence, and the sustainability of new product-driven growth.
  • Management sentiment remains constructive, with increased emphasis on complex electronics and automation initiatives relative to the prior quarter.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management cited ongoing uncertainty regarding tariffs and global trade dynamics, referencing "the recent IEEPA ruling by the Supreme Court last week and the new Section 122 global tariffs announced over the weekend."
  • The company highlighted shipment volume decline due to a customer's inventory adjustment but expects stabilization by Q2 2026.
  • A noncash goodwill impairment charge of approximately $51 million after taxes was recorded in Q4 due to continued heavy-duty segment pressures.

Final Takeaway

Dorman Products closed 2025 with robust new product innovation, strong margin performance, and further supply chain diversification, while setting 2026 targets for 7%–9% net sales growth and continued expansion in complex electronics. Leadership anticipates temporary margin pressure in early 2026 due to tariff impacts but expects profitability to improve as the year progresses. The company remains confident in its growth strategies across all segments, with ongoing investments in automation, product development, and targeted M&A, while closely monitoring global trade uncertainties and customer ordering dynamics.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Merck wins FDA approval of Numelvi for itching in dogs
data.description:
• The US FDA has approved Merck (MRK) Animal Health's JAK inhibitor Numelvi (atinvicitinib) for controlling pruritus (itching) related to allergic dermatitis in dogs.
  • The company said Numelvi is the first second-generation JAK inhibitor approved for the indication.
  • Numelvi will be available starting in the spring.

data.title: Nuveen Churchill Direct Lending slashes dividend by 20% to $0.36, $0.04 supplemental dividend, $50M buybacks
data.description:
• Nuveen Churchill Direct Lending (NCDL) declares $0.36/share quarterly dividend, -20% decrease from prior dividend of $0.45.
  • Forward yield 10.55%
  • Payable March 31; for shareholders of record March 17; ex-div March 17.
  • “We have reset our regular quarterly distribution to a level that considers the current interest rate and spread environment. In conjunction with the reset of our dividend, we are announcing a new $50 million share repurchase program, which demonstrates our confidence in the overall strength of our portfolio,” said Shai Vichness, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer of NCDL.
  • Additionally, the board approved a share repurchase program authorizing the Company to purchase up to $50 million in the aggregate of its outstanding common stock in the open market at prices below NAV per share.
  • See NCDL Dividend Scorecard, Yield Chart, & Dividend Growth.

data.title: EPR Properties outlines $400M–$500M investment plan for 2026 as portfolio diversification accelerates
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: EPR Properties (EPR) Q4 2025

Management View

  • CEO Gregory Silvers stated that "the fourth quarter capped a year of solid execution and clear progress toward accelerated growth," highlighting a 5.1% increase in FFO as adjusted per share and a 6.2% increase in AFFO per share for the year. Silvers announced significant portfolio expansion in championship golf courses and a major water park acquisition, emphasizing further diversification within the attraction sector. He noted, "As we move into 2026, we expect to build on our strong industry relationships while substantially increasing our investment spending."
  • Silvers underscored the company's capital recycling strategy: "By executing targeted dispositions, we strengthened portfolio qualities, reduce concentration and unlock capital to deploy into higher returning experiential investments."
  • The CEO also confirmed the successful closing of a $550 million public debt offering and establishment of a $400 million at-the-market equity program, which he described as "2 significant capital market initiatives that bolster our financial flexibility and fund our growing investment pipeline."
  • Silvers announced a "5.1% increase to our monthly dividend to common shareholders."
  • CFO Mark Peterson reported, "FFO as adjusted for the quarter was $1.30 per share versus $1.23 in the prior year, an increase of 5.7%. And AFFO for the quarter was also $1.30 per share compared to $1.22 in the prior year, an increase of 6.6%." Peterson highlighted total revenue for the quarter at $183 million, up from $177.2 million in the prior year, and noted percentage rents and participating interest for the quarter were $7.8 million versus $4.9 million previously.
  • Peterson stated, "Our net debt to annualized adjusted EBITDAre was 4.9x at year-end, which is below the lower end of our targeted range."
  • Silvers announced the retirement of CIO Gregory Zimmerman and the appointment of Ben Fox as the new Chief Investment Officer.

Outlook

  • Peterson introduced 2026 FFO as adjusted per share guidance of $5.28 to $5.48, representing an increase of 5.1% at the midpoint over the prior year. He added, "We expect a similar percentage increase in AFFO per share."
  • Investment spending guidance for 2026 was set at $400 million to $500 million, with disposition guidance for the same period at $25 million to $75 million.
  • Peterson clarified, "We expect percentage rent and participating interest of $18.5 million to $22.5 million."
  • Management noted the first quarter of 2026 is expected to be lower than the full year divided by four by about $0.11 per share due to seasonality.

Financial Results

  • Total revenue for Q4 was $183 million compared to $177.2 million in the prior year, with rental revenue increasing $7.9 million year-over-year.
  • FFO as adjusted for the full year was $5.12 per share, up from $4.87 in the prior year, and AFFO was $5.14 per share compared to $4.84.
  • Disposition proceeds totaled $34.5 million for the quarter and $168.3 million for the year, with gains on sales recognized both quarterly and annually.
  • The company closed on $550 million of new 5-year senior unsecured notes at a coupon of 4.75% and had $90.6 million of cash on hand at year-end.
  • AFFO payout ratio for the quarter and year was 68%.

Q&A

  • Michael Goldsmith, UBS: Asked about the confidence in achieving $400 million to $500 million in acquisitions. Silvers responded, "We wouldn't put it out there if we didn't have great confidence in it... we feel really good about where we're positioning for the beginning of the year."
  • Goldsmith also questioned the Topgolf transaction's impact. Silvers replied, "They're very much aligned with what we have said that the growth pattern needs to slow down to 3 to 5 units a year where they can hit kind of the demographic and location requirements that we kind of agree with them."
  • John Kilichowski, Wells Fargo: Inquired about cost of capital and conditions for tapping the ATM. Silvers indicated, "We are clearly entering the zone where it makes sense... maybe we could even further delever."
  • Bennett Rose, Citi: Sought updates on Sullivan County and theme park management changes. Silvers stated, "We've not had really any meaningful conversations with them... it's not built into our plan." On theme parks, he said, "We think that business is actually very, very... stable cash cow kind of business."
  • Anthony Paolone, JPMorgan: Asked about development versus acquisitions and cap rates. Silvers explained, "At least early part of this year, going to be more on the acquisition side... probably 70-30 acquisitions," with most investments carrying "an initial 8 handle on it."
  • Michael Carroll, RBC: Probed the timing of investments and Regal percentage rents. Silvers answered, "It's actually... weighted more towards the first half of the year," and expects percentage rents "up 2% over where they were last year."
  • Upal Rana, KeyBanc: Asked about the transaction market and upcoming labor negotiations. Silvers commented, "We're seeing our ability to participate in larger deals more," and on labor, "everybody is saying the right thing about wanting to avoid" strikes.
  • Jana Galan, BofA: Queried the education portfolio. Silvers noted, "The strength of that will allow us to capture good value if we want to do that and could be another lever that we pull to accelerate growth."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts focused on the sustainability of acquisition targets, cost of capital, tenant performance, and transaction pipeline, maintaining a neutral to slightly positive tone, with questions centering on execution confidence and sector trends.
  • Management consistently expressed confidence in guidance and strategic direction, with Silvers stating, "We feel really good about where we're positioning for the beginning of the year," but occasionally hedged with phrases like "we think" and "we hope," indicating a disciplined but optimistic outlook.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, both analysts and management maintained a similar tone, though management’s confidence in accelerated investment and portfolio diversification was more pronounced.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance for FFO as adjusted per share increased from the prior quarter’s range of $5.05 to $5.13 to a 2026 range of $5.28 to $5.48, with the midpoint growth rate rising from 4.5% to 5.1%.
  • Investment spending guidance shifted from $225 million to $275 million for 2025 to $400 million to $500 million for 2026, reflecting a substantial planned increase.
  • Disposition guidance narrowed from $150 million to $160 million to $25 million to $75 million, indicating a reduction in anticipated asset sales.
  • Portfolio diversification advanced, with new acquisitions in golf and water parks, and increased emphasis on fitness and wellness sectors, compared to a Q3 focus on hot springs and fitness.
  • Management’s tone was more confident regarding access to larger transactions and capital flexibility, while analysts maintained a cautious but inquisitive approach.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management highlighted macro pressures on consumers and expense increases, as well as potential labor negotiations in the broader entertainment sector.
  • The company is ceasing its practice of providing annual box office estimates, suggesting perceived stabilization but also reducing forward-looking granularity.
  • Silvers addressed asset-specific uncertainty, such as the lack of progress on the Sullivan County ground lease sale, and acknowledged the possibility of using the education portfolio as a lever for future growth.
  • Analysts probed cost of capital sensitivity, tenant performance, and the impact of major tenant transactions, indicating ongoing concern about market dynamics and execution risk.

Final Takeaway

EPR Properties concluded the year with strong growth in per share earnings, expanded its experiential portfolio through key acquisitions, and bolstered its balance sheet with successful capital market initiatives. The company enters 2026 with a robust investment pipeline, clear guidance for increased investment spending, and leadership transitions designed to support continued growth and diversification in the experiential real estate sector.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript
